speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: SCENE I. London. A street.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: The trumpets sound. Enter the young PRINCE EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, CARDINAL, CATESBY, and others

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The weary way hath made you melancholy.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: No, uncle; but our crosses on the way

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I want more uncles here to welcome me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nor more can you distinguish of a man

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than of his outward show; which, God he knows,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Those uncles which you want were dangerous;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your grace attended to their sugar'd words,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But look'd not on the poison of their hearts :

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: God keep you from them, and from such false friends!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: God keep me from false friends! but they were none.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter the Lord Mayor and his train

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: God bless your grace with health and happy days!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I thank you, good my lord; and thank you all.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I thought my mother, and my brother York,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Would long ere this have met us on the way

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: To tell us whether they will come or no!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Enter HASTINGS

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And, in good time, here comes the sweating lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: On what occasion, God he knows, not I,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: The queen your mother, and your brother York,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Have taken sanctuary: the tender prince

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Would fain have come with me to meet your grace,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But by his mother was perforce withheld.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Is this of hers! Lord cardinal, will your grace

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Unto his princely brother presently?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Can from his mother win the Duke of York,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: We should infringe the holy privilege

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Of blessed sanctuary! not for all this land

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You are too senseless--obstinate, my lord,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Too ceremonious and traditional

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You break not sanctuary in seizing him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The benefit thereof is always granted

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To those whose dealings have deserved the place,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And those who have the wit to claim the place:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Then, taking him from thence that is not there,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You break no privilege nor charter there.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But sanctuary children ne'er till now.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I go, my lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Exeunt CARDINAL and HASTINGS

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where it seems best unto your royal self.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If I may counsel you, some day or two

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your highness shall repose you at the Tower:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For your best health and recreation.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I do not like the Tower, of any place.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Is it upon record, or else reported

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Successively from age to age, he built it?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Upon record, my gracious lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: But say, my lord, it were not register'd,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Methinks the truth should live from age to age,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: As 'twere retail'd to all posterity,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Even to the general all-ending day.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  So wise so young, they say, do never

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: live long.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: What say you, uncle?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I say, without characters, fame lives long.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Aside

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I moralize two meanings in one word.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: That Julius Caesar was a famous man;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: With what his valour did enrich his wit,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: His wit set down to make his valour live

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Death makes no conquest of this conqueror;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: For now he lives in fame, though not in life.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What, my gracious lord?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: An if I live until I be a man,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I'll win our ancient right in France again,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter young YORK, HASTINGS, and the CARDINAL

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Now, in good time, here comes the Duke of York.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Too late he died that might have kept that title,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: You said that idle weeds are fast in growth

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He hath, my lord.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And therefore is he idle?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then is he more beholding to you than I.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He may command me as my sovereign;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: A beggar, brother?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A gentle cousin, were it light enough.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: It is too heavy for your grace to wear.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Little.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: My Lord of York will still be cross in talk:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Because that I am little, like an ape,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: He prettily and aptly taunts himself:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: So cunning and so young is wonderful.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My lord, will't please you pass along?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Myself and my good cousin Buckingham

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Will to your mother, to entreat of her

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: My lord protector needs will have it so.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, what should you fear?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My grandam told me he was murdered there.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I fear no uncles dead.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nor none that live, I hope.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: A Sennet. Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM and CATESBY

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Think you, my lord, this little prating York

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Was not incensed by his subtle mother

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No doubt, no doubt; O, 'tis a parlous boy;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He is all the mother's, from the top to toe.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As closely to conceal what we impart:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What think'st thou? is it not an easy matter

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To make William Lord Hastings of our mind,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For the instalment of this noble duke

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: In the seat royal of this famous isle?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: He for his father's sake so loves the prince,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: That he will not be won to aught against him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What think'st thou, then, of Stanley? what will he?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: How doth he stand affected to our purpose;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And summon him to-morrow to the Tower,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To sit about the coronation.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: If thou dost find him tractable to us,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: If he be leaden, icy-cold, unwilling,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Be thou so too; and so break off your talk,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And give us notice of his inclination:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For we to-morrow hold divided councils,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And bid my friend, for joy of this good news,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Good Catesby, go, effect this business soundly.

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: My good lords both, with all the heed I may.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: You shall, my lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit CATESBY

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, look, when I am king, claim thou of me

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The earldom of Hereford, and the moveables

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whereof the king my brother stood possess'd.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And look to have it yielded with all willingness.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We may digest our complots in some form.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt
